content.text: I’m guessing the issue here is a limitation associated with the expansion of
, which is a nonstandard and very old Hibernate thing from before JPA and from before Hibernate had support for
I’m guessing (but I have not tried it) that the workaround would be to do standard JPA things and just write out all the columns explicitly, avoiding the use of that syntax.
what you mean by writing all the columns explicitly?
It’s not precisely what I was thinking of, but if it works for you that’s great.

So there also appears to be a second(ary) issue here in that

in your entity, and so you have two things mapped to the

I don’t see any evidence at all that this is a bug.

Actually it is for money and I want to use just amount both of my attributes, so I don’t want to use B class, I need only amount. In @Column annotation I specified the name of corresponding area and this worked hibernate 5.x version with
Please continue this in the user forum or on Zulip.
is a reserved keyword in Oracle (see the

) so it’s not interpreted as a column name and no alias is prepended to it. I suggest renaming your column to something safer, and let us know if that solves your issue (I’m surprised this doesn’t cause more issues in general).
Yes, Oracle has the TO_DATE function, but I am not sure if it is a reserved verb for Oracle (
It works perfectly in other usages and actually it works as expected with previous Hibernate 5.6.15 + Oracle database.

I think renaming the column name would help but (please see TO_DATE → FROM_DATE naming conversion result in ticket description) I am not sure if this is the right way to handle the issue. I will discuss this with my team.
Did you try just quoting the column name in the filter definition?
, yes double quotes for column name helps and query is generated with alias and column name with double quotes and it works. thank you.
We will also convert “TO_DATE” column name to something else in our application.
Feel free to close the ticket, may be by adding some additional documentation for @Filter annotation mentioning the usage for keywords.
I agree that it would be very nice to support
I forgot to mention the JDK: Temurin-11.0.16+8

, the stack trace you shared doesn’t even include Hibernate in it - why do you think this is an Hibernate bug? From the looks of it it seems like Spring is triggering the exception, though I suspect you didn’t include the full stack trace here.
Furthermore, we require issue reports to include a simple
, using plain Hibernate, so please try to create one if you want us to look into this ticket.
Yes, It’s not a hibernate bug.
So it turns out it’s related to cascade persist.
When you report bugs in the Hibernate issue tracker, it is a strong requirement that you provide a reproducer test case that
what you are trying to prove with this screenshot. AFAICS it demonstrates that Hibernate throws a perfectly meaningful and correct exception: “unable to locate appropriate constructor”.
[This issue can be closed, unless the user follows up with something other than a screenshot of Hibernate working correctly.]

. This check was still available in hibernate5, but was removed on hibernate6.
This is a quite similar issue to
Both of these issues were reported as bugs, but neither of them are bugs. In both cases Hibernate is working as designed.
And contrary to the issue description—I just tested this on 5.6 to be sure—it was
affected the rendering of literals in Hibernate 5: not in HQL, and not even in criteria queries.
was only a global switch to turn on
everywhere. [So it is not true that this

entity attribute to a literal then Hibernate uses the

You are right. I did some more research on it.
In my case the root issue was caused by something else (see below).
Not sure how to handle my situation with >= 6.2  but let me explain. Maybe interesting for other readers…
In my old system with a 5.3.x  hibernate we have not configured literal handling. So AUTO is used.

This somehow renders all kind of String parameters as BIND parameters but long lists of ids in IN queries as INLINE…  This works for us also for the nationalized fields due to the fact that we also provide a SQLSERVER jdbc parameter  in the connection URL called:
So in our upper() case the bind parameter is send as unicode.
And large lists of IN values are send as INLINE like
You may see that we split large lists into chunks of 2100 which is the max IN limit of SQLServer. And we sometimes require some thousands. (Don't ask why. There are reasons
Then we upgraded to 6.2 and the AUTO mode is gone and now BIND is the default.

When we leave it on BIND the large IN lists are now parameters and our split trick is not working any more. The parameter limit for SQLServer is also 2100 like the IN limit so every time we reached this barrier the sql server complained.

Thats why we switched on INLINE to fix our IN limit issue. But this then renders all queries as INLINE and this also includes our case insensitive search implementation with the UPPER() function. Which now fails due to the “wrong” nationalized rendering.
No idea yet how to fix our code or how to implement a workaround.
And yes, I agree. Looks like a “change” and not a bug.
As a workaround I now use the ilike method in our code. This renders the value with the N'' prefix.
But it would be nice if we can change this to NOT cast the JPA criteria builder to something hibernate specific
, this is not a bug but rather it’s the intended behavior: the attribute's
is the same that would be reported through Java reflection, i.e. the generic-ly typed
class. Queries using that attribute path should work correctly, taking the
Can you tell us why you need to manually check the attribute’s java type? It would be interesting to know if there are use-cases where we could provide more information.
I’m writing a generic test framework for my company’s persistence modules.
, my test case tries to persist a randomized instance of
. Again the same code tries to randomize

Alright then, you’re going to have to change your test around a little bit, without relying on the attribute’s java type to determine the entity to persist. You could, for example, retrieve the entity class’ type parameters through java reflection, and use those to determine the association’s entity type to persist.
As I said in my previous comment though, this is not an Hibernate bug so I’m closing this Jira. Feel free to also open a discussion on
if you need more feedback or suggestions on how to improve your code.
